cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 220 miles SSE of Grand Cayman
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to turn northwest tonight, then move north-northwest across or just west of the Cayman Islands, cross western Cuba Monday night/early Tuesday, enter the southeast Gulf of Mexico Tuesday, and track northward toward the west-central Florida coast before curving across the peninsula toward Georgia/South Carolina late week.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: west-central Florida coast (near the Tampa Bay–Big Bend region)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Lower Florida Keys from Seven Mile Bridge southward to Key West, including the Dry Tortugas (Tropical Storm Watch)
weather_observation.warning_coast: Grand Cayman; Cuban provinces of Isla de Juventud, Pinar del Rio, Artemisa (Hurricane Warning) and La Habana, Mayabeque, Matanzas (Tropical Storm Warning)
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida peninsula and Keys, Gulf Coast from the Dry Tortugas northward to the Big Bend, and Atlantic coasts of North Florida through South Carolina later in the week
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Unlikely at this time (guidance currently <3 ft for NE Florida)
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (sustained 35–45 kt, higher gusts) possible late Wed night through Thu as Ian’s core moves across the peninsula.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Minor coastal flooding possible along the Atlantic beaches and lower St. Johns River with persistent on-shore flow.
weather_observation.rainfall: Heavy rain bands could bring 3–6 inches with localized higher totals, producing urban and river flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Dangerous surf and rip currents; brief tornado threat in outer rain bands.
